newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Closures hurt "perfect" NZ economy before election.
newsitem.headline: Closures hurt "perfect" NZ economy before election.

text.p: The collapse of a small New Zealand airline on Monday with the loss of 250 jobs put the focus on a slew of recent large shutdowns likely to hurt the conservative government five weeks before a general election.
Kiwi International Airlines went into liquidation as it succumbed to competition and unlucky breaks, from mechanical faults to volcanic eruptions, which played havoc with flights.
"The timing is certainly bad news for the government," said Canterbury University political scientist John Henderson.

Confectioner Arnotts said last week it was moving its biscuit-making operation to Australia, shedding 230 jobs in Auckland. Last month animal eartag manufacturer Allflex, often cited by politicians as a model New Zealand operation, relocated 130 manufacturing jobs overseas.

That followed hard on the heels of another New Zealand success story, Cedenco Foods, transferring its tomato paste operations to Australia and chopping 500 full-time and seasonal jobs in Gisborne, a rural area with heavy unemployment.

The National Party government, together with the independent Reserve Bank, has won international praise for running an apparently model free-market economy and its success there is likely to be a major campaign plank, said Henderson.
Finance Minister Bill Birch has trumpeted budget surpluses, low inflation, debt repayment and tax cuts as examples of National's success in managing the economy.
"These types of closures are not helpful for that overall theme...if business is relocating to Australia or closing down, that's bad news," Henderson said.
"We have been led to believe we have set up the perfect economy here, that we are ahead of Australia, yet firms are relocating. That does not look good."
Polls shows National has the strongest support, with around 35 percent, but opposition parties on the centre and left have over 50 percent and could form a government if they could agree to do so.

The economic nationalist New Zealand First Party and the left-wing Alliance both want to trim the Reserve Bank's independence and broaden its objectives beyond just price stability to include growth and employment targets.
Economists said the closures were an indirect result of tight monetary conditions for nearly two years as the Reserve Bank fights to get inflation back within its 0-2 percent target.
Many firms have had to grapple with high real interest rates and a steeply appreciating exchange rate.
"It's the downside of the tight discipline we have," said Infometrics economist Philip Wrigley.
"We've had an economic slowdown under way for quite a while and to some extent you have to expect a certain amount of bad news," he said. "These things do bite."
However, he pointed out that the latest figures for the June quarter suggested net job creation was still taking place at a surprisingly high rate despite the tight conditions.
